page.content: contd fron p14 local blacksmith, employing about five men, making and repairing the agricultural machinery for the farmers in the neighbourhood and from further afield. Mr Smith & one of his sons travel quite a distance to shoe horses With the coming of the oil industry many of the men trained in welding and fabricating to work across the firth at Nigg, building oilrigs, but in recent years many have been made redundant. Now at times workers are recruited for contracts repairing the rigs which come into the firth. When the contract is finished the men are paid off. In the village of Jemimaville, with a population of less than sixty there are three teachers, a doctor, two motor mechanics, a social worker, whose wife sells plants which contd on p16
